news.title: Word of the day
news.description:
Non-Operating Income
Non-Operating income is a company's revenue from activities different from its main business.
For example, for FMCG companies money received from sale of assets and interest income from investments are included in non-operating income.
This income forms a very small part of most companies’ total income.

news.title: 6-day course
news.description:
Theme: momentum investing
Day 1: Monday
There are different kinds of investing strategies used by different investors. One such strategy is called momentum strategy.
In recent years, it has gained popularity. It is a promising strategy but can also be risky.
In momentum, stocks that are climbing up are bought. They are sold as soon as they show signs of downward movement.
It’s a bit more complicated than that, but this is the gist of it.
It is basically taking a bet on the behaviour of investors to double down on stocks that are rising. And momentum investors aim to be one of the early ones to leave when a stock falls.
Further in this course, we’ll go deeper into how all of this works.

news.title: Featured question
news.description:
"Which is better to invest in MF : SIP route or lump sum investment"
There is no ’better’.
It depends on how your money stands.
First things first, for most normal investors, it does not make sense to accumulate money in your bank for months and then invest in one go (lump sum).
Like if you have a salary. It doesn’t make sense to accumulate the amount and then invest. SIP is more suitable here.
If you suddenly have a certain amount of money like an extra bonus you earned, a property sale, etc, then you can think of a lump sum investment.
In equity mutual funds, it is usually suggested to invest via the STP option.
In STP (Systematic Transfer Plan), you invest the entire amount in a debt fund and transfer it gradually to an equity fund.
It is like starting an SIP but instead of deducting money from your bank, it deducts money from a debt fund where you invested.
This reduces the chance of your lump sum investment getting caught in a single-day market spike — therefore reducing the risk a bit.
